4.1
Scenario 1

4.1.1
Asphaltene (type I) and hydrochloric acid
In the simulation cell including Asphaltene (I), HCl and toluene as the asphaltene solvent, after passing 500 ps the system reached the stable condition so that the thermodynamic parameters such as temperature, energy, and the density of the simulation boxes converged, balanced and stable condition achieved after 30 ps after stabilization stage (cf. SM, Fig. S6). The appeared RDF plot picks indicate two values of 2.8 Å and around 4.5 Å as the obtained picks for NAsphaltene – HHCl and OAsphaltene – HHCl, respectively, implying the strong tendencies between Asphaltene (I) molecules and hydrogen bonds (Fig. 12
a and b).


4.1.2
Asphaltene (type II) and hydrochloric acid
In this step, Asphaltene (II) was exposed to HCl to check the affinity between the two structures. RDF results for NAsphaltene – HHCl and OAsphaltene – HHCl show the pick approximately equal values of 2 Å and 2.2 Å, respectively (Fig. 12c and d). In comparison with the results for Asphaltene (I) (Fig. 12a and b), these simulated RDFs revealed the higher tendencies of Nitrogen and Oxygen existed in Asphaltene (II) to form a hydrogen bond through the available hydrogen cations in the simulation cell and in turn, more probability of sludge formation. Hence, Asphaltene (II) was selected to conduct scenario 2.



4.2
Scenario 2
In this scenario, we tried to investigate the tendency of Asphaltene (II) and Saponin molecules to the calcite surface in conditions where i) each one (either Asphaltene (II) or Saponin molecules) is present on the rock surface and ii) both of them are in exposure to the rock surface. Toluene molecules were also present as the solvent of Asphaltene (II) molecules (cf. SI, S2, Table S2). The distances of CAsphaltene (II) – CaCalcite and CSaponin – CaCalcite are approximately simulated equally (r ≈ 1.7 Å). Nevertheless, as Fig. 13
a and b depict, the g(r) value for CSaponin – CaCalcite is significantly over than that for CAsphaltene (II) – CaCalcite. Despite the equal distance of the picks in both cases (r ≈ 1.7 Å), this comparison highlights the more tendency of calcite structure to attract Saponin towards the surface which also represents a potential role of Saponin to decrease the wettability alteration of calcite slab by alleviating the Asphaltene deposition process.
Adding all the structures (i.e. Asphaltene (II), Saponin, and Toluene molecules on the calcite slab) to the simulation cell, yielded the shown RDF profiles for CAsphaltene (II) – CaCalcite and CAsphaltene(II) – CSaponin in Fig. 13c and d, respectively. While there is RDF pick at 1.7 Å in Fig. 13a, CAsphaltene (II) – CaCalcite formed a straight line with no pick (Fig. 13c) to highlight the role of Saponin presence in the simulation cell. On one hand, the tendency between CAsphaltene(II)– CSaponin has weakened the interaction between CAsphaltene (II) – CaCalcite, and on the other hand, the deviation of the asphaltene molecules affinity towards the Saponin molecules amplify the condition of less asphaltene deposition on the calcite surface and in turn, less wettability alteration towards water wetness. Comparison with the experimental findings, all these simulations results are in line with the results from the performed experiments in this study.



5
Conclusion
In the present study, the effects of sludge formation damage on the pay zone and its production were investigated. Since no substantial sludge is observed after mixing HCl acid with an asphaltene free crude oil, it is found to be a crucial component that forms induced sludge as a result of its interaction with injected acid during the field operations.
The amount of sludge increases significantly with an increase in the concentration of acid. Changing the wettability state towards oil-wetness after sludge deposition for all three types of used rocks in this paper represented the wettability state variation in oil reservoirs as another source of damage causing by sludge formation. In order to retain rock wettability to original water-wet state and to prevent formation of acid-induced sludge, two commercial surfactant and anti-sludge agent and the bio surfactant were examined. The commercial surfactant and bio-surfactant were able to maintain the rock water-wetness, however, in contrast to ZSCE bio-surfactant, the commercial one failed to maintain wettability state for a long aging time. Accordingly, the ZSCE bio-surfactant showed a better performance than the commercial ones to prevent the sludge formation. The results of molecular dynamic simulations show that hydrogen bond is the main force that actively leads to asphaltene deposition on the rock surface. Adding Saponin molecule to the simulation cells intervene in the interaction between calcite slap and Asphatene molecule as its affinity towards the calcite structure is higher than that of asphaltene molecule and introduces the used bio-surfactant in this study as an effective sludge formation inhibitor in reservoirs.

1
Introduction
Situated on the northwestern corner of the Eurasian continental plate, the Svalbard archipelago is located between 74 and 81° N latitude and between 10 and 35° E longitude, and is bounded to the north by the Arctic Ocean, to the west by the Greenland Sea, and to the south and east by the Barents Sea (Fig. 1
a). The study area is located in Ny Friesland, Spitsbergen (Fig. 1b). Ny Friesland is bounded to the west by north–south striking Wijdefjorden and the Hinlopenstretet in the east (Fig. 1b). A Cambrian-Ordovician carbonaceous succession is exposed along the south coast of the Hinlopen Strait/Hinlopenstretet (Fig. 1b). The Cambro-Ordovician succession in Ny Friesland, is a part of the North Atlantic/Arctic warm water carbonate platform on the eastern Laurentia margin (McKerrow et al., 1991; Stouge et al., 2012). The Ny Friesland Cambrian-Ordovician succession, which is about one km thick, includes a siliciclastic shoreline facies at the base, passing up to a shallow marine warm water carbonate platform (Fig. 1c).
Lower Paleozoic carbonate platforms with working petroleum systems are known from several places on the northern hemisphere; e.g., in Arctic areas such as North Greenland (Christiansen and Bojesen-Koefoed, 2021; Christiansen et al., 1989), the Timan-Pechora Province, Russia (Klimenko et al., 2011), western Newfoundland, Canada (Fowler and Douglas, 1984; Schwangler et al., 2020) and in NW Scotland (Parnell et al., 2018). Petroleum also occurs in Lower Paleozoic rocks from southern Scandinavia and the Baltic countries (Pedersen et al., 2007). The first attempt to drill for petroleum on Svalbard was carried out in 1920, and from 1963 until present-day, 18 test wells have been drilled without finding any areas of commercial interest (Senger et al., 2019), despite some shallow gas in Adventdalen (Ohm et al., 2019; Olaussen et al., 2019) and occurrences of both Carboniferous and Paleogene coals (Marshall et al., 2015; Nicolaisen et al., 2019; Senger et al., 2019; Van Koeverden et al., 2010). All wells were drilled in the southern and middle part of the Svalbard archipelago. Recent field work has revealed that the Cambro-Ordovician rocks in the north-eastern part of Spitsbergen are bituminous, and carbonate rocks are often stained with bitumen (Fig. 2
), as are age equivalent rocks in North Greenland (Christiansen and Bojesen-Koefoed, 2021; Christiansen et al., 1989). In fact, the presence of bitumen in the Ny Friesland area has been known for a long time. First reported by Gobbett and Wilson (1960), who referred to it as “organic material” based on thin section studies of the dolomitic part of the sequence. Later Vallance and Fortey (1968) reported “stinkstone” from the Valhallfonna Formation, emitting a strong odor of hydrogen sulphide when fractured. Similarly, Fortey and Bruton (1973) reported unusually high organic content, while Harland (1997) mentioned that fresh surfaces of limestones from the Olenidsletta Member of the Valhallfonna Formation often emitted a strongly sulfurous smell (“stinkstone”). Kosteva and Teben'kov (2006) described the hydrocarbon content as a strong smell of kerosene, while Kröger et al. (2017) stated that parts of the succession were bituminous. Despite these field observations, the bitumen in Ny Friesland has received limited attention.

Lee et al. (2019) used lipid biomarkers and stable isotope data to characterize and investigate the relationship between microbial communities and nutrient cycle of the Early–Middle Ordovician succession in Ny Friesland.
In this paper, we present results of total organic carbon (TOC), Rock-Eval pyrolysis, stable carbon isotope, thin layer chromatography–flame ionization detection (TLC-FID) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) to assess the source rock potential of the carbonaceous rock samples from the Cambrian-Ordovician strata in Ny Friesland, NE Spitsbergen (Fig. 1). The study also investigates the variation in type and distribution of source rock properties and organic facies between and within the Cambrian and Ordovician samples. This could shed light on whether source rock organic facies, rather than maturity, are responsible for differences in petroleum generation potential.


2
Geological setting and stratigraphy
Svalbard, northeastern Greenland and eastern North Greenland were part of a huge Cambrian to Ordovician carbonate platform on the margin of the Laurentian tectonic plate (Stouge et al., 2012). The Laurentian tectonic plate formed with the opening of the Iapetus Ocean between ca. 610 and 520 Ma (Hinchey et al., 2015). In Svalbard, Lower Paleozoic rocks are well exposed in several areas but with different states of preservation due to Caledonian Orogeny and the post-Caledonian burial history (Harland, 1997; Worsley, 2008).
Pre-Caledonian and Lower Paleozoic rocks of Svalbard have collectively been referred to as Hecla Hoek; see summary by Dallmann et al. (1999). These rocks are metamorphosed and structurally complex along the west coast of Spitsbergen, but on eastern Spitsbergen and the adjacent islands of Nordaustlandet, virtually unmetamorphosed Late Precambrian and Early Paleozoic sedimentary rocks have been preserved (e.g. Wilson, 1961). Acritarchs near the base of the 7500 m thick Precambrian sequence suggest a late Riphean age (Knoll, 1982; Knoll and Swett, 1987). These sediments show an exceptional preservation giving an unusual complete view of the late Proterozoic biota including stromatolites (Butterfield et al., 1994; Fairchild, 1991; Knoll and Swett, 1990; Swett and Knoll, 1985).

Smith and Rasmussen (2008) have reconstructed the Lower Paleozoic subsidence for the Ny Friesland area. The subsidence was modest during Cambrian, but increased markedly in the Lower Ordovician.
The thickness of the post Ordovician succession in the Ny Friesland area is uncertain. However, the Ny Friesland succession cannot have undergone deep burial because Conodont Alteration Index (CAI) values of 1 suggest a maximum paleotemperature of 90 °C (Bergström, 1980). This implies an overburden of about 3 km if we assume a temperature gradient of 30 °C/km. Oxygen isotope studies of trilobites from the Valhallfonna Formation has been tried as a proxy for the original water temperature, but this technique showed that the skeletal material was recrystallized yielding only crystallization temperature above 50 °C, in line with diagenetic alteration during enhanced burial temperature (Bennett et al., 2018).
Our study area on Ny Friesland belongs to the eastern tectonostratigraphic terrane of the Caledonian rocks of Svalbard (Gee and Teben'kov, 2004; Harland, 1997). Structurally the studied outcrop; Basissletta (Fig. 1d) on the east coast of the northern part of the peninsula is situated on the eastern limb of the north-south striking elongated Atomfjella antiform (Witt-Nilsson et al., 1998). The studied succession underwent minor folding during the late Caledonian stage with a NNW–SSE strike directions (Harland, 1997).

2.1
The profilbekken outcrop
The boundary between the Upper Polarisbreen Shale (Upper Precambrian) and the Lower Cambrian Tokammane Formation (Fig. 1c) is not exposed, but in nearby areas it is described as a sharp contact with an unconformity corresponding to the uppermost Ediacaran and perhaps lowermost Cambrian (Knoll and Swett, 1987; Stouge et al., 2012). We here briefly describe the outcropping succession along the Profilbekken, for detailed description and interpretations in palaeontology, facies and ages see: Fortey and Bruton (1973), Stouge et al. (2012), Lehnert et al. (2013), Kröger et al. (2017) and references therein.
At Profilbekken (Fig. 1c and d) the succession begins with a cross bedded burrowed fine to medium grained sandstone of the Blårevbreen Member followed by glauconitic sandy mudstone of the Topiggane Member, both assigned to the Lower Cambrian Tokammane Formation (Fig. 1c) (Fortey and Bruton, 1973; Stouge et al., 2012). These siliciclastic deposits represent shoreline to offshore condensed deposits, respectively and are onlapping the Precambrian craton. The base of the succeeding Cambrian shallow marine carbonates with stromatolites of the Ditlovtoppen Member of the Tokammane Formation (Fig. 1c) (Fortey and Bruton, 1973; Swett and Knoll, 1985) defines the shut off of the siliciclastic supply and the beginning of a thick (ca. 900m) succession of typical carbonate ramp deposits from inner to outer ramp facies (e.g. Schlager, 2003). The Lower Ordovician Kirtonryggen Formation (Fig. 1c) represents tidal flat to shallow-subtidal carbonate deposits under a tropical climate (Stouge et al., 2012). The unit can be interpreted as typical inner ramp deposits as described by Burchette and Wright (1992). The outcropping succession is ended by the upper Lower-Middle Ordovician Valhallfonna Formation (Fig. 1c). The basal unit of the Valhallfonna Formation, the Olenidsletta Member consists of dark grey to black bituminous limestone interbedded with calcareous mudstone and common cephalopod coquina (Fortey and Cocks, 2003; Kröger et al., 2017; Lehnert et al., 2013; Stouge et al., 2012) and was deposited during an increasing sea level (Kröger et al., 2017). The upper highly burrowed massive limestone of the dark grey-colored Profilbekken Member (Middle Ordovician) caps the exposed succession along the Profilbekken. Common phosphatic nodules, a few glauconitic thin beds and intensely bioturbated sediments suggest a condensed unit deposited below storm wave base. The unusual abundance of radiolarians (Maletz and Bruton, 2008), which might record plankton blooms in inner shelf or offshore areas suggest that the Valhallfonna Formation represent an outer ramp deposit.



3
Samples and geochemical analyses

3.1
Samples
A total of 17 carbonate samples representing the Cambrian-Ordovician succession along SW-NE trend stream-cutting exposure at Profilbekken, Ny Friesland, Spitsbergen (Fig. 1b and d) were taken. These outcrop samples include: Five samples from the Lower Cambrian Tokammane Formation and one sample from the Lower Ordovician Kirtonryggen Formation. These samples are fossiliferous, and had bitumen staining or paraffinic smell when crushed and some contained microbial laminated mudstone with dark organic laminae (Fig. 2). In addition, 11 samples were collected from dark grey to black organic-rich calcareous shale or argillaceous limestone from the Lower to Middle Ordovician Valhallfonna Formation (Fig. 1c; Fig. 2). The outer surface was removed prior to sampling to avoid weathering and oxidation. The samples were stored in plastic bags, labelled and transported into the laboratory. The samples were cleaned with water, dried overnight at room temperature prior to crushing for geochemical analysis. The samples were collected by the University Centre in Svalbard in 2015 and have been stored under dark, ambient and dry conditions at the Department of Geosciences, University of Oslo.


3.2
Geochemical analyses

3.2.1
Total organic carbon (TOC), total inorganic carbon, Rock-Eval pyrolysis and scanning electron microscopy (SEM)
For TOC and Rock-Eval pyrolysis, whole-rock samples were crushed into powder using a sling mill. For TOC determination, a Leco SC-632 instrument was used. Diluted HCl was added to the crushed-rock samples to remove carbonate, followed by repeated washing with distilled water, before drying. The samples were then introduced into the Leco combustion oven, and the amount of carbon in the sample was measured as carbon dioxide by an IR-detector. Inorganic carbon content was calculated based on sample weight differences before and after acid treatment. For Rock-Eval analyses, a HAWK instrument was used. Rock-Eval parameters such as S1 (free hydrocarbons released at 300 °C), S2 (petroleum products released due to pyrolysis of kerogen), S3 (CO2 produced by pyrolysis), T
max
 (temperature recorded at the apex of the S2 peak) and ratios such as oxygen index (OI = S3/TOC x 100), hydrogen index (HI = S2/TOC x 100) and production index (PI = S1/S1 + S2) were used to determine the source rock potential, and the degree of migrated hydrocarbon impregnation of the Ny Friesland samples. A standard sample, Jet-Rock 1, was run and values obtained were within the acceptable range given in NIGOGA (Weiss et al., 2000). The identification of mineral fractions from whole-rock polished thin section was performed by scanning electron microscope (SEM) technique of backscattered electron imagery.


3.2.2
Extraction of bitumen
For extraction of bitumen from the crushed rock samples, a SOXTEC™ apparatus was used. A mixture of 93% dichloromethane (DCM) and 7% methanol (MeOH) was used for extraction. Samples were boiled for 1 h and subsequently rinsed for 2 h (Weiss et al., 2000). Activated copper beads were added to the solvent as a boiling aid and to remove elemental sulphur. The extractable organic matter (EOM) was then analysed for bulk petroleum composition and stable carbon isotope (δ13C) values.


3.2.3
Thin layer chromatography–flame ionization detection (TLC-FID)
The bulk composition of the extracted organic matter was determined by the area percentage of the compound classes, determined by thin layer chromatography–flame ionization detection (TLC-FID) using a Iatroscan TH-10 MK-5 (Karlsen and Larter, 1991), equipped with Chromarod III silica-coated rods and linked with a computing integrator. 3 μl of the bulk extract was spotted at one end of the rods. The rods (10 at a time) were developed in solvents of different polarity; normal hexane for 36 min, enabling the saturated hydrocarbon fractions to move to the uppermost part of rods. After air drying for 2 min, the rods were developed in toluene for 8 min, causing the aromatic fraction to rise to about 50% of the length of the rods. The polar compounds (resins and asphaltenes) remain stationary at the point of sample application because these compounds are immobile in the solvents used for development. The rods were consequently dried at 60 °C for 1.5 min. Finally, the rods were put on the Iatroscan instrument at a scanning speed of 30 s/scan. Pure grade hydrogen (180 ml/min) and air (2.1 l/min) were used for the detector.


3.2.4
Stable carbon isotope analyses (δ13C)
Stable carbon isotopic ratios (δ13C) were measured for the bulk extract using a Thermo Fisher Scientific Elemental Analyser by Applied Petroleum Technology (Oslo, Norway). The samples were dissolved in a known amount of dichloromethane and 5 μl was transferred to a 5 × 8mm tin capsule. The solvent was evaporated in an oven at 50 °C. Then samples were loaded into an automatic sampler and were dropped into combustion reactor (Thermo Fisher Scientific Elemental Analyzer), held at a combustion temperature of 1000 °C. The excess supply of oxygen helps to flush the tin capsules which results in a temperature rise to 1700 °C. The produced water was trapped on magnesium perchlorate. The carbon dioxide was separated on a column interfaced to a Delta V Plus isotope ratio mass spectrometer (IRMS) from Thermo Fisher Scientific. A North Sea standard oil sample, NSO-1, was analysed as a reference. δ13C values are reported relative to the Vienna Pee Dee Belemnite (VPDB) standard.




4
Results

4.1
TOC and Rock-Eval pyrolysis data
Source rock screening data are presented in Table 1
 and are shown versus stratigraphic units in Fig. 3
. Five samples (SO-02/15, SO-03/15, WP-21, WP-22 and WP-23) belong to the Lower Cambrian Tokammane Fm., 11 samples (SO-01/15, SO-04/15, SO-05/15, SO-06/15, SO-07/15, SO-08/15, SO-09/15, SO-10/15, WP-26, WP-27, WP-28) belong to the Lower to Middle Ordovician Valhallfonna Fm., and sample WP-25 is from the Lower Ordovician Kirtonryggen Fm. The TOC and Rock-Eval data reflect great differences between the investigated formations, see Fig. 3. Richness is higher in the Ordovician compared to that in the Cambrian samples.
The TOC and remaining hydrocarbon potential (S2) values for the Tokammane Fm. samples are extremely low, ranging from 0.05 to 0.16 wt% and 0.04–0.08 mg HC/g rock, respectively (Table 1 and Fig. 3). HI values for the Tokammane Fm. samples range from 30 to 73 mg HC/g TOC (Table 1 and Fig. 3). Pyrolysis data from samples with very low TOC (<0.4 wt%) values, should according to Hunt (1996), be ignored. All the Cambrian samples have S2 values lower than 0.2 mg HC/g rock (Peters, 1986) and thus confirm that most of the Rock-Eval pyrolysis data, including PI and Tmax are not significant (Peters, 1986). In North Greenland, Lower Cambrian shelf carbonates of the Portfjeld Formation are similarly marked by very low TOC contents, suggesting no source potential (Christiansen et al., 1989). Thus, despite being presented on the cross plots, discussion on the Rock-Eval data of the Cambrian succession will be very limited in the subsequent sections.
In the investigated Lower to Middle Ordovician Kirtonryggen and Valhallfonna Fm. samples, TOC and S2 values range from 0.25 to 2.09 wt% (average 0.74 wt%) and from 0.41 to 5.85 mg HC/g rock (average 1.73 mg HC/g rock), respectively. HI values for the Kirtonryggen and Valhallfonna Fm. samples range from 123 to 424 mg HC/g TOC (average 209 mg HC/g TOC). T
max
 for the Kirtonryggen and Valhallfonna Fm. samples range from 438 to 446 °C, except for sample SO-04/15 in which case the T
max
 is 458 °C, while production indices (PI) range from 0.03 to 0.13 (average 0.08).



4.2


TLC–FID and δ13C data
TLC-FID and stable carbon isotope analyses were performed on eight Lower to Middle Ordovician Valhallfonna Fm. samples (SO-01/15, SO-04/15, SO-05/15, SO-06/15, SO-07/15, SO-08/15, SO-09/15 and SO-10/15) and two Lower Cambrian Tokammane Fm. samples (SO-02/15 and SO-03/15) (Fig. 1c, Table 2

). Total extractable organic matter (EOM) was generally low and uniform (0.25–0.53 mg/g rock) in the Ordovician samples, except in sample SO-01/15, where the EOM yield was higher (i.e. 2.17 mg/g rock).
The extracts from the Valhallfonna Fm. samples consist of 12.23–32.76% saturated hydrocarbons, 4.71–41.25% aromatic hydrocarbons and 46.52–74.78% polar compounds, i.e. asphaltenes and resins (Table 2). The TLC-FID data also reveal that polar compounds are the dominant fraction in the extracts of the Valhallfonna Fm. samples, with polar/hydrocarbon ratio >1 (range 1.26–2.97, Table 2), except for sample SO-01/15, which contains more hydrocarbon compounds than polar fraction. Saturated hydrocarbons dominate over the aromatic hydrocarbons, thus saturated to aromatic hydrocarbon ratios (Sat/Aro) are greater than unity (range 1.05–4.81) for the Valhallfonna Fm. samples, except for SO-01/15 and SO-07/15, in which case the values are 0.30 and 0.67, respectively (Table 2). The Sat/Aro ratios for the two Tokammane Fm. samples are 22.20 and 63.01.
The EOM yields for the SO-02/15 and SO-03/15 samples of the Tokammane Fm. were 0.32 and 1.17 mg/g rock, respectively (Table 2). The SO-02/15 and SO-03/15 samples had very uniform bitumen composition with 32.76 and 33.46% saturated hydrocarbons, 0.52 and 1.51% aromatic hydrocarbons and 66.72 and 65.03% polar compounds, respectively. The Sat/Aro ratios for the SO-02/15 and SO-03/15 samples are 63.01 and 22.20, respectively. However, the values for the Tokammane Fm. samples are suspicious due to the very low content of TOC.
δ13C values for the samples show intermediate values and range from −28.4 to −30.9‰ (Table 2). The maximum variation in δ13C for the investigated samples reaches 2.5‰ (Table 2). The Cambrian Tokammane Fm. samples (SO-02/15 and SO-03/15) show heavier δ13C values (−28.40 and −28.80‰) than any of the eight Ordovician Valhallfonna Fm. samples, which show δ13C values from −29.70 to −30.90‰.


4.3
Scanning electron microscope (SEM)
SEM analysis was carried out on two Cambrian (SO-02/15 and SO-03/15) and four Ordovician (SO-01/15, SO-07/15, SO-08/15 and SO-10/15) samples (Fig. 4
). In the dolomitic SO-02/15 sample, only traces of iron and rutile (TiO2) were identified (Fig. 4a). Sample SO-03/15 is calcite with traces of dolomite and contains iron oxide and kaolinite (Fig. 4b and c). The Ordovician samples are dominated by calcite minerals with dolomite found in lesser amounts (Fig. 4d and e). Pyrite has been identified in all Ordovician samples investigated. Framboidal pyrite crystals are very common in the Ordovician samples (Fig. 4d–h). Apatite is also very common in all Ordovician samples investigated and is here exemplified in Fig. 4d and e. Other minerals observed in all the Ordovician samples, despite less frequent, include quartz and kaolinite. Sphalerite was identified in sample SO-10/15.



5
Discussion

5.1
Thermal maturity
Thermal maturity levels of the investigated organic matter in the Ny Friesland samples were determined directly from results of T
max
 and indirectly from interpretation of production index (PI) and HI (Figs. 5–7


). For the Cambrian samples, the T
max
 values and other maturity parameters are considered unreliable due to low amounts of TOC and only trace amounts of residual hydrocarbons (S2 peak). For the Ordovician samples, low to moderate PI values suggest most bitumen in these samples to be in situ (Figs. 5 and 6a). T
max
 data for the Ordovician samples suggest early-to- mid mature, corresponding to 0.70–0.85% Ro (Peters and Cassa, 1994). The slight difference in T
max
 values vertically is within the uncertainty of measurements.
Lack of preservation of the post Ordovician succession in Ny Friesland makes it difficult to assess the effect of burial on the maturity. Bergström (1980) reported a Conodont Alteration Index (CAI) of 1, which suggests a maximum paleotemperature of 90 °C for the Ny Friesland Lower Paleozoic carbonate rocks. Assuming a geothermal gradient of 30 C°/km, this corresponds to burial depth of 3 km.
Despite good consistency in maturity estimate from PI and T
max
, there is still some discrepancy for the Ordovician samples (Fig. 5b). To elaborate on this, 75% of the Ordovician samples (9 out of 12) are immature based on PI (i.e. PI < 0.10), but they are in the oil window maturity as inferred from T
max
 (438–449 °C), see Fig. 5b. The other 25% of the Ordovician samples (i.e. three samples including samples SO-08, SO-10 and WP-27) show relatively high PI values of 0.10–0.13, indicating marginally mature petroleum at best. However, these latter samples are also characterized by the lowest organic carbon content (0.25–0.39 wt% TOC), compared to the 0.43–2.10 wt% for the 75% Ordovician samples. Elevated PI could be due to minor migrated bitumen (Abay et al., 2017). This is in agreement with the bitumen stain, visible, for example, on the surface of the WP-27 sample (see Fig. 2e). This shows that more data is needed for definite maturity assessment and conclusion is tentative.


5.2
Petroleum generation potential and kerogen type
Illustration of TOC vs. S2 (Fig. 6b) for the samples ranks the relative richness of source rocks (Peters, 1986). Peters (1986) used a minimum cut off values of 0.5 wt% TOC and 2.5 mg HC/g TOC S2 for a potential source rock at the beginning of oil generative window (0.5–0.6% Ro).
The investigated Lower to Middle Ordovician samples fulfil the criteria of minimum TOC content for carbonate rocks and suggest fair to good source rock potential for petroleum generation (Table 3, Fig. 6b). More importantly, all investigated Lower to Middle Ordovician samples have S2 values greater than 0.2 mg HC/g rock, confirming the validity of the data (Peters, 1986).
HI values for the investigated Ordovician samples point to a mixture of Type II and Type III kerogen (mixed oil- and gas-prone) at present (Fig. 7). However, it is imperative to note that woody Type III OM obviously does not exist in source rocks of Cambrian-Ordovician ages. Thus, Type III kerogen may represent poor preservation of algal material.
Sample WP-26 with HI value of 424 mg HC/g TOC, indicates the highest oil source potential in the dataset (Figs. 7–8
). This may reflect rich hydrogen content per unit carbon from organic contributions such as algal or bacterial organic matter. The high HI value for sample WP-26 may also indicate intervals of highly anoxic conditions during deposition of the Olenidsletta Member of the Valhallfonna Formation, as also reported for the analogous formation elsewhere (Schwangler et al., 2020).
Following sample WP-26, four samples (SO-06/15, SO-07/15, WP-28 and SO-01/15) have the next higher HI values (206–280 mg HC/g TOC), while the range in HI in the remaining seven Ordovician samples is between 123 and 193 mg HC/g TOC. Thus, the Ordovician samples form three groups based on the HI values (Fig. 8a). Interestingly, the S2/S3 ratio, also known as the hydrocarbon type index (Peters and Cassa, 1994) is consistent with the HI trend (Fig. 8a). In the investigated Ordovician samples, except in sample WP-27, the S2/S3 is greater than 5, a value suggesting that most of the organic carbon in the Ordovician samples is reactive and capable of oil generating (Peters, 1986). On the other hand, the WP-27 sample has a S2/S3 value of 3.24 which is typical of gas generation (Fig. 8a).
Maturity will reduce the HI values to look less oil-prone, as is the case in central Spitsbergen (Koevoets et al., 2016). Emplacement of Late Mesozoic sills and dykes which are common in Svalbard have been reported to have locally affected the maturation of source rocks (Abay et al., 2017; Mørk and Bjorøy, 1984; Senger et al., 2014). Such intrusions exist south of Buldrevågen (Fortey and Bruton, 1973), which is to the southeast of Ny Friesland. However, the proximity of this intrusion to the studied rocks is not known and, the thermal effect is thus uncertain. Moreover, the investigated Ordovician samples have generally similar TOC content (Table 1), suggesting that the variations in HI is reflecting the kerogen type, which in turn reflects differences in organic facies.
Despite moderate source rock potential and possible facies variation among the Ordovician samples, it appears that there is a relatively good linear relationship between TOC and HI (Fig. 8b). Such relationship may suggest an overall uniformity of marine-organic matter type with good preservation (Abay et al., 2018), suggesting that the organic carbon is more oil prone (Dahl et al., 2004). Still, it is true that some samples may have better convertibility of TOC to petroleum than others despite having a relative lower TOC content. For example, samples WP-26 and WP-28 have HI values of 424 and 222 mg HC/g TOC, respectively, despite the fact that TOC in the later sample is about 1.5 times higher than in the former (Table 1, Fig. 8b). This suggests that a large proportion of the organic matter in sample WP-26 is composed of reactive carbon as compared to a non-generative inert portion (Abay et al., 2018; Dahl et al., 2004).
In the Ordovician samples, the petroleum generation potential must have been higher than suggested by present-day data (Figs. 6 and 7). Assuming immature rocks (T
max
 <430 °C), the kerogen in samples such as SO-01, SO-06, WP-28 and SO-07 can be traced back to a Type II/III from their current Type III/II (Fig. 7b). Part of the reason for low HI can also be oxidation in outcrops (Graham et al., 1990). As shown in Table 1 and Fig. 3, pre-existing free hydrocarbon compounds in the kerogen, related to oil already generated (S1) is very low in the Ny Friesland samples. Such low values are expected in outcrop samples due to volatilization and oxidation, and the fact that the rocks are not presently in an active petroleum generation thermal state. This low values may also reflect uplift and loss of petroleum products.


5.3
Bulk geochemical properties of bitumen
In this study, TLC-FID and δ13C data on extracts were available only for two Cambrian (SO-02/15 and SO-03/15) and eight Ordovician (SO-01/15, SO-04/15, SO-5/15, SO-06/15, SO-07/15, SO-08/15, SO-09/15 and SO-10/15) samples (Table 2, Figs. 9–11


).

5.3.1
TLC–FID data
Low bitumen yields of the investigated samples are indicative of in situ generated petroleum as opposed to migrated petroleum (cf. Karlsen et al., 2004), in agreement with Fig. 6a. However, the yields of the investigated samples are greater than the bitumen yield reported by Karlsen and Larter (1991) for in situ organic matter in carbonate cemented rocks. Thus, it may tentatively be argued that the Ny Friesland samples could also contain some migrated petroleum as well as in situ bitumen. Interestingly, the extractability of the samples from the Ny Friesland is similar to that of migrated hydrocarbons from Lower Cambrian samples in North Greenland (Christiansen et al., 1989; page 62). The relative proportion of petroleum fractions reveals that the aromatic and polar fractions reflect greater variation than the saturated fractions (Table 2, Fig. 9). Particularly, the content of saturated hydrocarbons is low in the Ny Friesland samples when compared with that of common crude oils (Tissot and Welte, 1978), as can be seen in Fig. 9, and with core extracts on the Norwegian Continental Shelf (Abay et al., 2014; Bhullar et al., 1999b; Karlsen et al., 1995; Karlsen and Skeie, 2006; Karlsen and Larter, 1991). This dissimilarity in bulk composition between common oils and the Ny Friesland extracts is supported by data for a North Sea oil (NSO-1), included as a standard, which is characterized by 50% saturates, 33% aromatics and 17% polar fractions (Fig. 9).
Extract yields and low content of hydrocarbon fractions (i.e. saturated and aromatic hydrocarbons) and/or higher polar contents like these could be related to microbial degradation of saturated HCs and other processes, such as water washing and evaporation/weathering (Abay et al., 2014; Bhullar et al., 1999a; Karlsen et al., 1995; Karlsen and Larter, 1991) or to greater content of sulphur-aromatic compounds of kerogen deposited in marine carbonate rocks (Waples, 1985). Furthermore, a Sat/Aro ratio of less than 5 for all Ordovician samples investigated is generally consistent with hydrocarbons sourced from carbonate source rocks and/or biodegradation in reservoirs (Wang et al., 2015).


5.3.2
δ13C composition of extracts
The range of δ13C (Table 2) for the investigated Ny Friesland samples is similar to oils of Lower Paleozoic age (Zdanaviciute et al., 2012; Christiansen et al., 1989). Fig. 10 shows the δ13C values of the extracts plotted versus sample coordinates. Based on their δ13C values, the investigated Ny Friesland samples can be divided into three trends or groups (Figs. 10 and 11). The first includes the Cambrian samples (i.e. SO-02/15 and SO-03/15) with relatively heavy (more positive) δ13C ratios. The second and third groups consist of the Ordovician samples, which are characterized by lighter (more negative) δ13C values. Among the Ordovician samples, in general, more negative δ13C values were found for the SO-08/15, SO-09/15 and SO-10/15 samples, located towards the north-eastern part of the study area (Fig. 10).Various factors might explain such differences. According to Peters et al. (1989), oils that are derived from the same type of organic facies and that are of similar maturity will generally differ only up to a maximum of 1–1.5‰ δ13C. Because the maturity range is limited in the investigated Ny Friesland samples (Fig. 5), it cannot have significant effect on the δ13C. Thus, δ13C variation of up to 2.5‰ for the investigated samples (Table 2) could be attributed to organic facies, consistent with the kerogen type differences already suggested (Fig. 8). The trend observed within the Ordovician samples (Fig. 11), further suggests that the difference in the carbon isotope values is real, and depicts the depositional condition of the sediment (Fig. 11).
Interestingly, the variation in δ13C appears to follow the geographic sample location, where the isotopes become lighter from SW to NE (Figs. 10 and 11). Such regional variations in δ13C values from a heavier to a lighter δ13C value often reflects changes from a less marine or dysaerobic facies in the proximal part of the basin, to a more anoxic, marine facies in the distal part (Karlsen et al., 1995). Devonian oils and OM samples from the Norwegian Sea and the UK have δ13C values in the range of −32‰ (Karlsen et al., 1995), believed in part due to assimilation of isotopically light methane by bacteria. It is not well known why OM from carbonate platforms in the Paleozoic can be isotopically light, but assimilation of biogenic methane on carbonate platforms is certainly possible.



5.4
Scanning electron microscope (SEM)
The presence of kaolinite in the Cambrian SO-03/15 sample may suggest leaching of silicate minerals at shallow burial depth (Bjørlykke, 2015). Such minerals are common in oxic depositional systems. The presence of abundant framboidal pyrite crystals in the Ordovician samples (Fig. 4d–h) reflects a marine anoxic depositional system (Skei, 1988; Taylor and Macquaker, 2011), consistent with the HI and δ13C data. Framboidal pyrite occurs with apatite. Phosphatic horizons such as apatite from the investigated Ordovician succession in Ny Friesland have also been related to upwelling (Fortey, 1980). Framboidal pyrites is also suggestive of high sulphide supply from organic matter, as opposed to euhedral pyrite, which is linked with iron oxide minerals and detrital clay minerals (cf. Taylor and Macquaker, 2011). The presence of framboidal pyrite within the Ny Friesland Ordovician samples thus indicates that bacterial sulfate reduction prevailed during deposition and early diagenesis (Taylor and Macquaker, 2000). In contrast, occurrences of iron oxide and kaolinite and absence of framboidal pyrite in the Cambrian samples suggest that sulfate reduction did not occur, and this is in accordance with the low TOC content in these samples.


5.5
Organic facies
We have above discussed differences in petroleum potential for the Ny Friesland samples. Because the maturity for the Ny Friesland samples is not very high (Figs. 5–7), these differences in petroleum potential could be attributed to the organic facies, including the organic matter input, and the preservation processes such as depositional environment and biological activities (cf. Jones, 1984).

Jones (1984), defined seven organic facies (A, AB, B, BC, C, CD and D) on the basis of HI for thermally immature or early mature samples. Such classification of organic facies is on the basis of organic constituent, without regard to the inorganic component. The HI of immature samples can be roughly estimated from the present-day HI and maturity data (Waples, 1979). Thus, in Fig. 7b, we can trace back (extrapolate) the samples along the maturation pathway to their approximate immature position (Ro <0.5%). Accordingly, for the Ordovician Ny Friesland samples, three types of organic facies are recognized: B, BC and C (Fig. 12
).
Only sample WP-26 plots close to organic facies B, which is typified by TOC >1.5 and HI of >350 (Jones, 1984). However, using an extrapolated HI value of about 500 mg HC/g TOC at a maturation of 0.5% Ro (Fig. 7b), sample WP-26 would plot inside organic facies B. Samples SO-06/15, SO-07/15, SO-01/15, WP-28 and possibly also WP-25 (Fig. 12a and b) are plotted inside organic facies BC, characterized by HI of 200–350 (Jones, 1984). In Fig. 12a and b, these samples are plotted very close to organic facies C and D. Taking into account their likely original HI values, these samples are clearly outside this category and thus are assigned to organic facies BC (shaded area in Fig. 12a and b). Samples SO-04/15, SO-05, SO-10, SO-09, SO-08 and WP-27 belong to organic facies C, which according to Jones (1984), has HI values between 50 and 200 mg HC/g TOC. Samples indicated as organic facies C, can be considered similar to those in organic facies BC in terms of their original HI values. But they are distinctly different, as also indicated in Figs. 6–8.
The difference between sample WP-26 (organic facies B) and those samples of organic facies BC and C points to variations in organic matter or differences in oxygenation and preservation. Hence, some samples such as sample WP-26 of the Valhallfonna Formation could have been deposited under relative anoxic condition. This may represent a part of the Olenidsletta Member of the Valhallfonna Formation (Fig. 1c), in which lamination is well known. Anoxic conditions for the Ordovician Valhallfonna Formation samples can also be inferred from the abundant occurrences of pyrite in samples such as SO-01/15 (Fig. 4). In SO-10/15, there is also sphalerite and apatite, often associated with upwelling. These conditions, in general, favoured preservation of organic matter of relatively good quality. This organic-rich source rock is probably related to a relative sea level increase during the deposition of the Olenidsletta Member of the Valhallfonna Formation, also described by Kröger et al. (2017) and Fortey and Bruton (1973) based on faunal and sedimentological evidences. On the other hand, poorer source rock quality (i.e. low in HI) for the rest of the samples may suggest deposition which grades to a more shallow water condition, thus promoting bioturbation and oxidation (cf. Jones, 1984; Pratt, 1982, Fig. 12 a and b). Even though bioturbation is rare in the Olenidsletta Member, the overlying Profilbekken Member comprises bioturbated limestone beds (Stouge et al., 2012).
In summary, comparing bulk geochemical composition (isotope and TLC-FID), TOC and Rock-Eval data, we identified at least three different organic facies types (B, BC and C) for the Ordovician succession in Ny Friesland. In the samples investigated, these differences reflect mainly variations in depositional environments and related biological processes as well as changes in marine/phytoplanktonic input, resulting in alternating high and low source potential (Herbin et al., 1993). Thus, compositional differences in the Ny Friesland samples is chiefly due to source facies, rather than differences in thermal maturation.



6
Conclusions
Geochemical data from carbonate rocks of Cambro-Ordovician succession outcropping in Ny Friesland, Svalbard suggest that:

•
The Lower Cambrian Tokammane Formation samples and the Lower to Middle Ordovician Kirtonryggen and Valhallfonna formation samples show great variation in TOC, Rock-Eval data and bulk geochemical data on extracts.


•
Based on T
max
, the maturities of the investigated samples range from early to peak oil window, corresponding to 0.70–0.85% Ro.


•
The Tokammane Formation samples are generally lean in organic matter, and constitute no source rocks for petroleum generation.


•
The Lower to Middle Ordovician samples of the Kirtonryggen and Valhallfonna formations have moderate TOC contents suggesting fair to good source rock richness. Their relatively high HI values are interesting with respect to OM quality. While most samples show moderate potential, HI values as high as 424 mg HC/g TOC at T
max
 of 444 °C suggest very good source rock intervals for oil generation.


•
The differences in HI values of the Ordovician samples may reflect diversity of organic facies including biological processes in the sediments. But, more work is needed to understand this better. In particular, it is crucial to investigate more data for TOC contents, isotope signatures, organic petrography and biomarker analysis.

Introduction
Drilling of boreholes is a standard practice for the recovery of oil and gas from subsurface reservoirs. The depth of these boreholes can be several kilometers below sea level and there may be many variations in the formation properties through various subsurface strata along the depth of the borehole. In addition to the naturally occurring formation fractures, the drilling process inherently induces cracks and fissures along the borehole wall and under normal conditions this does not pose any problems for the drilling operations. However when the stresses induced by drilling are too high, the fissures may open up and cause an unwanted influx/efflux of formation/drilling fluids between the formation and borehole (Brudy and Zoback, 1999). Such conditions are one of the main causes for a phenomenon known as “kick”, that occur due to sudden loss of stability in the pressure of the fluid column in the borehole. In severe cases where these kick events cannot be controlled, a loss of the wellbore may occur, sometimes also accompanied with a loss of the drill-string due to collapse of the wellbore, resulting in severe economic liability for the operators. Thus the drilling operations are carefully monitored using various logging-while-drilling (LWD) tools and post drilling well logging techniques (Ellis and Singer, 2007). However, to the best of the authors’ knowledge there is no LWD technique currently in use to measure or monitor such influx/efflux event.
Commonly used early kick detection systems monitor various operational parameters from the drilling platform (Nayeem et al., 2016). These systems amongst other tools usually also involve the monitoring of drilling fluid volume and pressure being circulated into the drill-string (Orban et al., 1991). In the event of a kick that may occur several kilometers down the borehole, it takes several minutes before the effects of a kick are measurable in the operational parameters by these systems. Such information delay, in critical cases, may lead to blowouts.
There has been a consistent effort to develop LWD tools for monitoring fluid influx/efflux in boreholes. Some of these techniques include physical measurement of the pressure of the drilling fluid near the drill bit (Andrew, 1942; Grosso and Jr., 1988), use of radioisotopes for measuring changes in density of drilling fluid (Murphy and Coope, 1985), measurement of dielectric constant of the drilling fluid (Rodney, 1990) and acoustic techniques measuring the sound speed in drilling fluid (Wu, 2008) or the amount of gas bubbles in the drilling fluid (Taherian and Garcia-Osuna, 2016). Most of these tools however are either not very sensitive to small influx/efflux or require additional instrumentation to be added to the bottom hole assembly (BHA) which is neither very practical nor economical in an already complex drilling system.
The use of ultrasonic measurements in LWD is common for imaging the borehole surface for fissures, borehole profile and assessment of rheological properties of the formation (Ellis and Singer, 2007). Fig. 1 is a schematic representation of a typical BHA with ultrasonic LWD tools. The drilling fluid is circulated from the surface, through the center of the drill-string, through the drill bit nozzles into the borehole, carrying the rock cuttings back to the surface through the annulus between the borehole and the BHA. The typical flow velocity of the drilling fluid along this axial component is around 2–7 m/s (Ferguson and Klotz, 1954). While drilling, the typical rotation speed of the BHA is about 1–3 revolutions-per-second (rps) (Chevron et al., 2021). In the event of an influx/efflux, the formation/drilling fluid will flow along the radial direction as depicted in Fig. 1. It is desirable that the same ultrasonic LWD tools can also be used for the detection and quantification of influx/efflux in the boreholes while drilling as it would eliminate the need for major modifications or increased complexity in the BHA.

Considerable work has been done by various researchers to evaluate Doppler ultrasound for characterizing radial flow in boreholes. Pulsed wave (PW) and continuous wave (CW) Doppler ultrasound methods for estimating radial flow volumes and blockages during production logging are described by Razi et al. (1995), Ravenscroft et al. (1998) and Nyhavn et al. (1999). Although radial flow quantification in production logging may seem similar to influx/efflux while drilling, the speed of rotation of the tool and frequency of ultrasonic probes used in LWD make the direct application of production logging tools to LWD quite challenging. PW Doppler ultrasound has been studied further under laboratory conditions for post-drilling well logging by Saito and Niitsuma (2001) and Monnier and Guillermin (2003). These papers however have not investigated the applicability of the their methods under LWD conditions. Details of the Doppler ultrasound parameters used, signal processing methods and their influence on the radial flow estimates have also not been discussed in these papers.
This paper evaluates the performance of PW Doppler ultrasound for the quantification of radial flow velocity from small fissures in a borehole wall in a laboratory scale experimental setup mimicking LWD conditions. The influence of various factors of the LWD environment on PW Doppler measurements and the limiting conditions when applied to existing LWD tools for flow quantification are also discussed. A method for estimating the fissure geometry using the PW Doppler signal is also described and compared with conventional ultrasonic pulse-echo imaging used in LWD tools.


2
Methodology
The major parameters influencing ultrasonic Doppler measurements in a LWD scenario can be narrowed down to: the geometrical constraints of the drill-string inside a borehole, properties of drilling fluid, ultrasonic transducers and associated acquisition parameters, and the motion of the drill-string. The effect of each of these parameters on PW Doppler measurements are discussed in this section.
The borehole environment typically operates under high pressure and temperature, the effect of these parameters on Doppler measurements have not been evaluated in this study.

2.1
Experimental setup
The experimental setup consists of a flow chamber as shown in Fig. 2 which emulates the geometrical and influx flow conditions inside a typical borehole. For simplicity, water is used as the working fluid for all experiments described in this paper as the sound velocity in water is close to the sound velocities typically observed in typical water-based drilling fluids (Motz et al., 1998). Water-based drilling fluids typically contain barite or bentonite as the major dispersed constituent. Further, the attenuation of ultrasound in water is very low compared to that is drilling fluids (Motz et al., 1998). However, ultrasound pulse-echo is routinely employed in LWD which suggest that the amplitude of 2-way ultrasound propagation between the transducer and borehole wall is usually at acceptable levels. 2.2
PW Doppler parameters
This work aims to explore an ultrasound Doppler method which can be directly applied to existing LWD tools used for imaging the borehole wall. Publications on LWD field measurements from leading drilling companies indicate the use of ultrasonic transducers in a frequency range of 100kHz–1MHz (Shrivastava et al., 2019; Blyth et al., 2021; Maeso et al., 2018; Longo et al., 2012; Leonard, 2016). These publications also suggest the use of unfocused transducers, although focused transducers have also been reported in some papers. Further, the element size of the transducers, as reported in these publications, range between 1/2 to 3/4inches in diameter.
Considering these transducer specifications, PW Doppler is well suited as it can be applied with a single element transducer and enables the measurement of radial flow velocities at multiple points along the ultrasound beam. The influence of various factors of the LWD environment on Doppler ultrasound are detailed in this section.

2.2.1
PW Doppler - fundamentals
There is a wide variety of literature on the basic principles of PW Doppler ultrasound, for example by Hoskins (2019), but a very brief overview of its fundamentals specific to the terms used in this paper are discussed here. Fig. 5 outlines the basic principles involved in PW Doppler processing. A series of ultrasonic pulses are fired into the fluid where velocity estimates are desired and the pulse-echo signals (also called as RF signals) are recorded (Fig. 5a). The time dimension in each pulse-echo signal is termed as the “fast-time” dimension which is analogous to the depth in convention pulse-echo ultrasound imaging. The firing rate or the frequency between each firing is called as the pulse repetition frequency (PRF). Several such RF signals are recorded over the “slow-time” dimension with intervals equal to PRF to form a “packet” of RF data. The number of RF signals in each packet is called as the “observation-window”. The RF signals in each packet are then demodulated to obtain the in-phase quadrature (IQ) signal which contains both amplitude and phase information of the signal. The IQ signal is sampled at specific fast-time locations, producing a slow-time signal for each packet (Fig. 5b). Ths slow-time signals are then transformed into the frequency domain using Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to obtain the PW Doppler spectra (Fig. 5c). This spectra contains information about the velocity components in the flow.

2.2.4
Pulse length
Velocity estimation by PW Doppler relies primarily on the back-scattered ultrasound signal from microscopic scatterers in the fluid. Rayleigh scattering is the primary mode of this back-scattered ultrasound signal and by nature is a very weak signal. The use of long pulse lengths is thus essential to obtain an adequate power of the PW Doppler signal. The pulse length is the product of the wavelength of ultrasound and the number of cycles transmitted per pulse. It directly impacts the power of the Doppler signal and spatial resolution of velocity estimates. Further, the pulse length has an inverse relationship to the bandwidth of the transmitted pulse, which influences the bandwidth of the PW Doppler spectra and in turn the accuracy of velocity estimates. Additionally, the axial resolution and variance in velocity estimates depends on the size of the sample volume used for Doppler processing, which is usually equal to the pulse length. Considering these factors, it is desired to have long pulse lengths with 8–10

λ
 per pulse in typical PW Doppler acquisitions. In a typical LWD scenario, the distance between the ultrasonic transducer and the borehole wall is around 25–50 mm as discussed in Section 2.1, which is equivalent to 16–32

λ
 for a 1MHz ultrasonic transducer. A PW Doppler acquisition using the conventional 8–10

λ

λ

Motion of drill-string
The motion of a typical BHA while drilling can be broken down into its axial, circumferential and radial components as depicted in Fig. 8. The axial component is primarily the rate of penetration (ROP) and is typically around few m/hr. From an ultrasonic measurement point of view, this velocity is very low and unlikely to have any impact on acquisition parameters. The circumferential velocity is primarily due to the rotation of the BHA and is typically around 1–4rps. Unlike conventional ultrasonic pulse-echo measurements, PW Doppler acquisitions usually require more than 50–100 signals per location for obtaining reasonably low variance in velocity estimates. In practice the ultrasound transducer would acquire these signals while the tool is rotating. 2.4
Signal processing chain
RF data acquired from the Verasonics Vantage 256 system (Verasonics Inc. Redmond, WA, USA) is first reshaped into a 2D matrix with the columns representing the slow-time dimension and rows representing the fast-time dimension. The time interval between acquisitions in two adjacent columns is equal to 1/PRF. A observation-window of 200 was used for our experiments which was optimized as discussed in Section 3.1.1. A clutter filter is then applied on each of the pulse-echo acquisitions to remove the stationary and slow-moving signals caused by the initial pulse, back-wall echo and any transverse motion in the fluid column. The clutter filter used is a Kaiser windowed FIR filter of order 50 for most of the results discussed in this paper except in Section 3.1.3 which discusses the application of polynomial regression filter for reducing the observation-window. The RF signal is then demodulated to the base band to obtain the IQ signal. The PW Doppler spectra for each sample volume is then obtained by using a Hamming windowed FFT in the slow-time dimension with an 80% overlap and subsequently averaging over the fast-time dimension. The window length used for the FFT is approximately equal to the time it would take for a random scatterer in the water jet to travel a distance equal to 1 sample volume. This depends on the velocity of the water jet being evaluated. The peaks in the PW Doppler spectra are used to calculate the mean velocity of the fluid in each sample volume. Considering that we use short pulse lengths for our experiments, the PW spectra has a poor SNR and some form of dynamic threshold estimator is required for isolating the peaks in the PW spectra. An estimator utilizing the “sum of median and standard deviation” for each PW spectra was found to be effective. Further, the turbulent nature of the water jet results in a large variance in radial flow velocities of the jet at any given point in the slow-time dimension. This causes a broadening of the PW spectra and induces a high variance in the position of the peak maxima between subsequent signals at the same position. This effect is illustrated in Fig. 9 which shows the PW spectra from two subsequent packets (orange and blue) of the flow from a 
∅
10 mm orifice with a velocity of 0.5m/s. To make the peak selection unambiguous and minimize the variance in mean velocity estimates, the centroid of the PW spectra was found to be effective instead of choosing the peaks with the absolute maximum amplitude.






3
Results and discussion

3.1
Velocity estimation
The flow profile during an influx/efflux scenario is inherently complicated and would have a broad distribution of flow velocities even at a particular spatial location. Although mean the velocity at each spatial location would yield significant information for kick detection; PW Doppler has the potential to reveal the complete velocity distribution which may be leveraged for more detailed diagnostics. Fig. 10 shows the PW Doppler spectra for a mean radial flow velocity of 0.5m/s from a 
∅
10 mm orifice. The various flow velocities at each spatial location (depth) is easily evident by the spread of the PW spectra in the Y direction, and the amplitudes indicating the relative quantity of flow with specific velocity values. Further, the clutter at 0 velocity, which has been filtered out in this PW spectra, can also yield information about the flow velocity in the axial direction using Eq. (3). The PW spectra at each depth location can be analyzed individually as seen in Fig. 9 to extract the mean velocity estimates as discussed earlier.

The performance of PW Doppler on mean velocity estimates was further evaluated experimentally considering the constraints with respect to observation-window, pulse length and distance between the transducer and borehole wall.

3.1.1
Effect of observation-window on variance of mean velocity estimates
The observation-window directly influences the spatial resolution of PW Doppler when applied for LWD as explained in Section 2.3. It is therefore desirable to have small observation-windows. However, the observation-window also influences the variance of mean velocity estimates by PW Doppler and the choice of an optimal observation-window is important. Experiments using the 10 mm circular orifice (Fig. 3) and 0.3m/s influx velocity (
≈
 23ml/s) were repeated with different observation-windows and the variance in mean velocity estimates are plotted in Fig. 11. The variance seems to be leveling off by a observation-window of about 150. The observation-windows as mentioned in Fig. 11 are post clutter filtering of the RF signal and thus depending on the type of clutter filter used, the observation-window should be accordingly increased while acquisition. For our experiments, an FIR filter of order 50 was found to be the most optimal, so the observation-window must be increased by 50. A observation-window of 200, including the initialization of clutter filter, was used for all experiments discussed further. Section 3.1.3 discusses a method to reduce the observation-window without compromising the variance in mean velocity estimates.

This may be sufficient as a go/no-go detection for influx/efflux, but is not sufficient when high resolution measurements are desired. It is possible to reduce the tool speed to for making high resolution scans, but it is desirable if this can be avoided.
The use of FIR filters for clutter suppression is very common due to its stability, linearity and time invariant properties. These types of filters however require samples equal to the filter order for initialization, which consequentially increases the observation-window. Polynomial regression filters are known to be used in color flow imaging where there is a similar requirement of small observation-windows for high frame rate imaging (Leonov et al., 2019; Bjaerum et al., 2002). Polynomial regression filters have a steep frequency response and do not require additional samples for initialization, they are however not time invariant which makes it difficult to tune the filter to achieve a constant frequency response.

3.2
Fissure geometry estimation
Ultrasonic LWD tools are routinely employed for obtaining high resolution images of the borehole wall with one of the important objectives directed at detecting the presence of fissures on the surface of the borehole wall. The imaging resolution of such fissures however is typically very low even for high-resolution LWD tools (Li et al., 2019), partly because of the hardware limitations in incorporating such tools with the BHA. These ultrasonic LWD tools typically map the amplitude and travel time of the echo from the borehole wall for imaging.

The presence of fluid influx/efflux from such fissures provides the opportunity to process the ultrasound signal in another way viz. the Doppler spectra, which can potentially be also used for imaging the geometry of such fissures. With this objective, 2D scans were performed, using a robotic scanner as described in Section 2.1, on both the 

∅
10

The integral of the power of the IQ signal along the slow-time dimension at each measurement point was found to give the best SNR for geometry estimation and these are shown in Figs. 16(a) and 16(c). A high SNR of about 30 dB can be observed between the region with influx (the orifice) and the regions away from the influx. Conventional backwall-amplitude images as used in LWD tools (Li et al., 2019) were also generated from the same orifice plates as shown in Figs. 16(b) and 16(d). The poor SNR of about 6 dB in these images is evident, and it is quite difficult to identify the orifices from these images. The backwall-amplitude maps in Figs. 16(b) and 16(d) have several artifacts surrounding the orifice and are caused due to geometrical features within the experimental setup and would not exist in a typical borehole setting.
Further, the dimensions of the orifice was estimated using a threshold of 96th percentile for the IQ signal power integral shown in Figs. 16(a) and 16(c). The estimated dimensions of the 

∅

The deviations in the estimate in Y direction for the 19 × 1 mm slot orifice can be attributed to the point spread function (PSF) of the ultrasound transducer which is about 4 mm at 50 mm depth for the 1/2inch, 1MHz unfocused transducer used in these experiments. The effect of the PSF is to diffuse out the edges in an ultrasound image and this consequently causes an overestimation in the dimensional estimates. The deviations in the other dimensional estimates are relatively small and can be attributed to the variance in the signal amplitudes in the images.



4
Conclusion
The possibility of utilizing PW Doppler for the estimation of influx/efflux flow velocities and the geometry of the fissures have been explored using a laboratory scale setup. An attempt has been made to define a set of boundary conditions for the application PW Doppler in a LWD setting.
The use of short pulse-lengths and packet sizes than what is conventionally used in PW Doppler is explored and their effect on the variance of velocity estimates has been demonstrated. It has been possible to obtain mean velocity estimates with a standard deviation of 0.05m/s using a pulse-length of 4

λ
. It is also possible to use a shorter pulse-length of 2

λ
 but at the expense of an increase in the standard deviation of mean velocity estimates to 0.2m/s. Though this may be a very high error for quantitative purposes, it can be useful as a radial flow detection mode when the tool to borehole wall spacing is too small for example during a phase of high tool eccentricity. It is also demonstrated that influx velocities up to a lower limit of 0.2m/s (15ml/s from 
∅
10 mm orifice) can be reliably estimated using PW Doppler.
The possibility of using alternative clutter filtering methods like the Savitzky–Golay polynomial filter to reduce the observation-window of PW Doppler without any adverse impact on the accuracy of mean velocity estimates is demonstrated. This is particularly useful for real-time PW Doppler acquisition while drilling at speeds of about 1–3rps.
Lastly, the use of PW Doppler for imaging fissures and estimating their geometry with influx/efflux in boreholes is demonstrated and compared with conventional pulse-echo amplitude imaging used in LWD tools. PW Doppler imaging delivered a significantly higher SNR of about 30 dB compared to an SNR of about 6 dB by conventional pulse-echo amplitude imaging. Although, PW Doppler is by far the superior method compared to pulse-echo amplitude imaging, it requires an active influx/efflux from the fissure to be possible to apply. PW Doppler can thus be used as a complimentary tool in conjunction with conventional methods.
The experiments in this paper were aimed at exploring the possibility of using PW Doppler with conventional LWD tools and thus have been conducted using water as the working fluid for the sake of simplicity. Considering the promising results demonstrated in this work, further evaluation of the performance of PW Doppler using real drilling fluids of different properties should be the next step towards the deployment of this method for regular field use.

1
Introduction
Upstream hydrocarbons production and transportation must deal with multiphase flow, with a variable and often unpredictable ratio between gas and liquid phases. This ratio is fundamental in determining the flow regime along the pipe, as well as in tuning the appropriate fluid processing at the receiving terminal plant, in order to guarantee the efficiency and safety of the assets.
The need to model and predict the variability of multiphase propagation has been broadly addressed in the literature (Brennen, 2005; Henry et al., 1971; Hsu, 1972; Gudmundsson and Celius, 1999; Kumar et al., 2020). A fully theoretical approach, consisting in using mathematical equations and analytical models, cannot be employed in a real scenario, due to the impossibility of knowing the initial status and the governing equations with the required accuracy (Falcone and Alimonti, 2007; Agwu et al., 2022; Taylor, 1935). Other solutions make use of numerical simulations or experimental setups arranged in laboratories, which lack validation on real scenarios (Andrade et al., 2022; Chaves et al., 2022). The current frontier is instead represented by computational methods (Yan et al., 2018; Babakhani Dehkordi, Colombo, Guilizzoni and Sotgia, 2017), which employ models driven by the data, either available in the literature (Kanin et al., 2018; Alhashem, 2019; Al-Naser et al., 2016; Alhashem, 2020; Kanin et al., 2019; Gene et al., 2019), generated synthetically (Andrianov, 2018; Babanezhad et al., 2020) or collected from real transportation assets (Aziz AL-Qutami et al., 2018; Góes et al., 2021; Ye and Guo, 2013; Qiang et al., 2021).
What emerges from the research survey just discussed is that a lot of attention currently stands towards virtual flow metering systems (Bikmukhametov and Jäschke, 2020) or flow rate estimation in multiphase pipeline systems, yet (according to the best of the Authors’ knowledge) the current literature is rather poor with regards to successfully tracking and monitoring the location of multiphase fluid batches/slugs: even though the latter is an equally important matter, it still remains a quite unexplored area of study. The work presented here fills such a research gap by proposing a data-driven methodology that allows to follow the position of diverse oil-gas mixtures moving along a pipeline at the velocity of the fluid flow. Our proposed method starts from a practical example to highlight its effective applicability on real scenarios: as such, we consider pressure signals collected by Eni for two full months (February 2020 and March 2020) in discrete locations along a 7.8 km oil-gas multiphase transportation asset located in Italy. We have designed and tested several features, directly derived from the collected pressure data, which are able to describe the variability of the multiphase batches flowing along the conduit. Such features are tuned for tracking a given sequence of mixtures along consecutive acquisition stations: the latter task is performed by a supervised learning model, based on Extremely Randomized Trees (Geurts et al., 2006). As said, the main technical novelty of our approach consists in an automated tagging and tracking process of the different multiphase slugs that enter/exit the pipeline, along with the opportunity to track their position and movement along the pipe. Besides that, our methodology is based on cheap and standard pressure measurements, which are typically already installed in many pipeline assets; it leverages on a simple machine learning algorithm; compared to most research works in the topic of oil/gas multiphase propagation, we have worked with an experimental dataset that is concurrently large enough (more than 15 billion examples) and collected from a real pipeline transportation system. Other key elements are an accurate synchronization of the measurements, the real time transmission and multichannel processing of the data.
The remainder of the paper is structured as follows. Section II provides an overview of the case study. Section III describes the processing steps applied to the data, whereas Section IV and Section V respectively explain how to tag and track oil-gas mixtures. Lastly, Section VI draws the conclusions.


2
Case study description
The work presented here makes use of pressure data collected for two months (from February 1st, 2020 to April 1st, 2020) by a proprietary vibroacoustic continuous monitoring system (e-vpms® technology (United States of America Patent No. US10401254B2, 2019)), installed on an upstream oil & gas network located in South Italy, which conveys a mixture of gas and oil products. The flowline has a length of approximately 7.8 km with altimetric variance, is characterized by 12” ID pipes and continuously operates with a service pressure comprised between 30 and 44 bar.
The gas-to-oil ratio (GOR) typically ranges between 50 and 250, with an average value of approximately 200, based on separator measurements collected on-site. Fig. 1
 displays the satellite track of the conduit (red curve) and the location of the three acquisition stations installed on the line itself (highlighted by yellow pins and respectively labelled as A, B and C). The production well (A) is upstream with respect to the Oil Centre (C). Each e-vpms® sensing unit is equipped with a dynamic hydrophone, which records pressure transients within the multiphase fluid. The sampling rate has been set to 1 kHz: recalling that the acquisition time spans over two full months (e.g., 60 days), the total number of recorded samples per sensor is more than 5 billion. Table 1
 reports the relative distance between each acquisition unit and the production terminal installed at station A.
In a pipeline fluid transportation system, every interaction with the pipe or with the flow generates acoustic signals that propagate as guided waves within the fluid itself. Considering multiphase pipelines, a sensor in contact with the fluid (e.g., an hydrophone) can measure pressure transients (i.e., sounds) having different characteristics according to the variable gas/liquid ratio of the moving mixture: during a normal operation regime, the related pressure fluctuations are neither constant nor periodic, yet their statistical features can be analyzed and exploited, using data-driven techniques, to define one or more propagation regimes.
Given such a context, two distinct acoustic propagation processes have been observed. The first one is related to pressure transients generated by the flow regulation equipment (e.g., pumps, valves, etc.): these transients propagate within the pipe at the sound velocity 


v
s


 depending on the type of fluid transported. More specifically, if the pipe was entirely filled with gas, one would observe a propagation velocity of a few hundred m/s; if one instead conveys liquid oil, 


v
s

 (Unalmis, 2015): it is clear that sound velocity measurements can be exploited to estimate the gas-oil ratio. In principle, 


v
s

Unfortunately, in high GOR regimes (like in our case, the average GOR is around 200) the propagation is very chaotic and turbulent due to the dominant presence of gas: as a consequence, pressure transients tend to decorrelate very rapidly (after a few hundred m) such that the aforementioned technique cannot be employed to estimate 


v
s


. We have in fact verified this aspect on our experimental datasets by correlating the signals collected at the two closest stations (e.g., A and B), obtaining unsatisfactory outcomes.
The second propagation process is instead related to the fluid flowing within the line, which travels at the flow velocity 


v
